abstract.text: An object that manages custom bar button items that you add to the shortcuts bar above the keyboard on iPad.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: object to add app-specific actions to the shortcuts bar on iPad. The center of the shortcuts bar displays typing suggestions for the user. You can install custom bar button items that lead or trail the typing suggestions.
You can add custom items to the shortcuts bar on iPad only. On iPhone, the text input system ignores the contents of the
You don’t create instances of this class directly. Instead, you get an input assistant from the

property of the responder object whose keyboard you want to modify. When the keyboard is onscreen, UIKit automatically searches the responder chain for a text-input assistant object. Typically, you assign the text-input assistant to the object that becomes the first responder. However, you can also assign it to a parent responder object to share a set of shortcuts among multiple children.
Organize the bar button items you create for the shortcuts bar into groups. A

object manages each group of items, and each group may contain a single item or several items. UIKit displays as many items as possible based on the available space. When there’s not enough space for all of the items, UIKit collapses each group of items down to a single representative item.
The following code configures the items of the shortcuts bar. After creating the bar button items, this code creates a group and assigns that group to the
property. The resulting items appear before the typing suggestions.

code: // Get a UITextView object of the current view controller.
// Use a nil action to display the individual items.
// Display the items before the typing suggestions.
// Get a UITextView object of the current view controller.
// Use a nil action to display the individual items.
// Display the items before the typing suggestions.

inlineContent.text: To hide shortcuts altogether, set the
properties to empty arrays. Doing so hides only the shortcuts and doesn’t hide the typing suggestions. For information on managing the typing suggestions, see

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A group of one or more bar button items for placement on a navigation bar or shortcuts bar.
An object that represents the textual interpretation of a spoken phrase that the user dictates.
A set of methods a responder uses to implement simple text entry.
The input assistant to use when configuring the keyboard’s shortcuts bar.
A set of methods for interacting with the text input system and enabling features in documents.
An object that manages custom bar button items that you add to the shortcuts bar above the keyboard on iPad.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the user can hide the shortcuts bar.
A button that appears next to the text preview in the keyboard in visionOS.
The array of button item groups to display before the typing suggestions.
The array of button item groups to display after the typing suggestions.
An object that reports the type of input your app receives.
An intermediary between a document and the text input system.
The current text input mode.
A set of methods that defines features for keyboard input to a text object.
The autocorrection style for the text object.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
